message: This project has completely confiscated my life, darling.
Consumed me as only hero work can.
My best work, I must admit. Simple, elegant, yet bold. You will die.
Words are useless! Gobble-gobble-gobble-gobble-gobble! Too much of it, darling, too much!
That is why I show you my work. That is why you are here.
Five projects. Each one started because we couldn't ignore the problem.
Which interests you?
Resume generator. Cover letters automated. Chatbots explaining his work.
You are using one right now, darling. Tools he actually needs, so he built them.
The interface replicates LinkedIn. Not to deceive—to demonstrate capability.
(Password: 'demo')
A family tree for 100+ relatives. Free work treated like paid work.
Requirements gathered. Iterations delivered. Everything runs on free hosting because that was the constraint.
Most see constraints as problems. We see them as parameters.
Timeline tracker. Every commitment logged. Every promise visible.
Built because he got tired of lying to himself about consistency.
The gap between intention and reality made visible. Usually uncomfortable.
Social platform for finding friends. Club-based. Ambitious vision.
Started January. Paused September.
Not because it failed. Because unless it is ready, it is not.
The origin. University project. Ancient now.
But that's when the realization hit: I enjoy building this more than circuits.
So electronics engineering became software engineering. Mostly.
The approach? Code so clear machines understand it.
A senior colleague once fed his abstractions to an LLM. It understood immediately.
Not genius, darling. Just refusing to be clever when clarity works better.
He once told account managers: if you find bugs in my code, it is my fault.
Then shipped features. They found none.
Not because perfection—because proper testing before handoff.
Here is what doesn't make it to portfolios: false starts. Abandoned ideas. Approaches that failed.
Bigcampus paused because execution wasn't worthy of vision yet.
Infinite Days exists because self-deception needed accountability.
The work is real. The struggles are real. The rest is just... presentation.
Football training: random movements, observe impact, iterate success.
Recently realized—that's reinforcement learning. Feedback and adjustment.
Now wants to apply that same curiosity to systems that learn. Not trendy. Connected.
Inherited messy code once. Refactored. Added types. Added tests.
You touch code, you leave it better. That is the responsibility.
I never look back, darling. It distracts from the now.
But standards? Those stay consistent. No shortcuts. No compromises.
Every project must justify its existence. Every line must earn its place.
Why me? Because I say 'no' when the world expects 'yes.'
No capes. No half-measures. No accepting baseline as acceptable.
He allows me to be bold. So few people do, darling. So few.
Go. Confront the problem. Fight. Win.

message.text: And call me when you get back, darling. I enjoy our visits.
